description:
Those titles you're hearing now are some of the 21 films being released in cinemas this week. Finding a film to watch can be like hunting for truffles, lots of scrabbling around and no guarantee it's to your taste. For a documentary that's irresistible, I'd recommend Dark Horse, subtitled The Incredible True Story of Dream Alliance. If you're not there already, Dream Alliance is a racehorse funded by a syndicate in the south Wales town of Blackwood led by local barmaid and supermarket cleaner Jan Vokes. She bred racing dogs and pigeons, so thought it might be time for a horse, even if she had to raise it on her allotment. What happened next is retold in the documentary directed by Louise Osmond and produced by Judith Dawson, which won the Sundance Audience Award for World Cinema back in January. I asked Jan Vokes why she was happy to tell her story, what did she want to get across?

"I think it was the emotion of it. It was what the horse meant to us. It was never about the racing as such. I mean, the horse was, when he was one of the syndicate, we paid £10 a week and he put his winnings in. He helped keep itself in the racing and I think he was like an anchor to all of us."
